This lunar lander model was downloaded as a 3ds file from NASA.
The file was converted to zpr, fixed to allow slicing, and exported in .zpr, VRML (.wrl), and .STL format. Pics from left to right:
ProJet 4500, 3dedit pro screenshot, stl, ProJet 3500 HD Max encased in wax Update:
The legs need to be thickened to support the weight of the model. I'll see what i can come up with without sacrificing the accuracy too much. Step 1 will be hollowing out the main body and adding a drain hole in the middle of the rocket engine.

Good luck printing this on an FDM machine.
I may have to thicken the legs by offsetting the shells.
I will be printing it on a ProJet 4500.
maybe a zprinter 650 as well.
Also got it printed on a projet 3500 HD Max.
Should have an update on that soon once finished post processing.

comments.text: Great job! I've been waiting for someone to make a good one of these. About when do you think it'll be finished?
comments.author: Caleb

comments.text:
whenever i get some time to work on the STL. Im working on a lossless conversion from the original file so that I keep all geometries. I used an auto-repair feature to fix the STL after conversion, which deleted some shells in the ladder and the stabilizer thrusters. I need to offset all of the legs so that they can support the full weight of the model (not just the moon-weight).
Lastly, I plan to hollow the body and put a drain hole for support material in the main thrusta.

Logo for the troll version of Sgrub. Sgrub, Sburb, and Homestuck belongs to Andrew Hussie. :o)

Got a purty new Mk5 and relay board but don't know where/how to attach the relay board? This design makes use of two existing holes under the motherboard. I used T10x16mm screws since I had them lying around. Use wood screws, sheet metal screws, whatever. Put two screws through the holes from the inside of the Makerbot to mount the Standoff. Use four screws (or only two if you are feeling lucky) to attach the relay board to the Standoff.

Even though I have a heated build platform, I was having trouble getting the first layer to stick on blue painters tape so I gave up and used a raft. The gcode file reflects that. Printed with Mk5, still tweaking settings, currently 220*C, 0.42mm layer thickness, 40 mm/s feedrate. 36 minute total print time.

description.text:
Some of my friends and I will be attending this year's Star Trek Convention in Las Vegas and I thought it would be fun to create some communicators for us to wear. These were designed to allow you to screw in M3 grub screws to the side so you could use them with a magnet to attach to your clothing.  
I realize there are dozens of Communicator options already made by other Trek fans, but I wanted to model it myself. Come visit us at the X Prize table for photos and show off your creations.

title: U-Profile (10x10mm) and Makerbeam Holder / Clip screw mount

description.text:
Aluminium u-profiles are quiet cheap and I like to use them for a lot of different cases. Eg. using them as a cable channel. Mainly it wasn't handy to fix / screw the u-profile onto a surface if the U should be up
For this reason and because i didnt find cheap mountings in a tool store I decided to design a small tiny holder for 10x10 u-profiles. Also working with Makerbeams.
Best print results with supports and depending on the calibration with a raft.

title: A parameterized hypocycloid gearbox for a NEMA 23 motor part of the Cogburn design for Team Grit Robotics

description.text: Team Grit Robotics is working on a better design for a robot that we hope will be in the DARPA DRC Challenge in June of next year. We plan to share the designs with the open source community like Thingiverse. This is a gear box that works with the python script credited in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3617. Two dxf files are produced that are then used in this gearbox that is 100:1 in a height not much thicker than a skate bearing. Other bearing choices are possible in the script.

comments.text:
Hi,
What is the crescent moon shaped piece for? What other parts does the drive require aside from the motor?
comments.author: triops124

comments.text: A 608zz bearing (Skate bearing) is set against the axle of the stepper motor.  The crescent piece is carefully super glued to the axle of the motor and makes a cam that fits the inner diameter of the 608zz bearing.
comments.author: triops124

comments.text:
Thanks for the prompt reply.
That's unfortunate that it loses 90% of the power.
I found this thingiverse "thing" as I am looking for a dirt cheap, mostly compact reduction mechanism 100:1 or 1:100 ratio that doesn't slip. 3D printing seems to be the cheapest source of such a device.
Basically, the fast-rotation-end would be moved by a roller which moves as a rope reels in. This would power a low-rotations-end that would move a sliding rod (less that 100 grams) without slipping.
Back to the drawing board as the saying goes!
comments.author: KarlCastleton

comments.text: I liked it for many of those same reasons.  Plan to come back to it some day and put it over the top.

author: KarlCastleton

description.text:
A friend gave me a 1957 Oldsmobile 88 "barn car". I have been fixing it up and finally have it on the road. I wanted to have a radio, but haven't been able to get the 40lb AM tube radio working yet. I found a company that makes new configurable radios (http://www.retrosound.com/), but they didn't have a faceplate or knobs that matched my car. I designed an adapter that slides on the front of the radio that is close to what the original radio looked like. I scanned the knobs and faceplate and created CAD models.
My challenge now is to find an inexpensive way to chrome them. For now I used Chrome spray paint, but it isn't that shiny

comments.text: You will want to have it vacuum metallized. Check out this company http://www.chrometechusa.com/

I'm surprised howw fast they printed and that they work being so tiny! Use an M2 set screw for them. I may change the number of set screw holes if people have problems printing...keep me posted A Pfierce version will also be released soon, with some different

comments.text: When you use rhino, save with the ascii format, not the binary, and it will save you a lot of space on the stl files.
comments.author: naldarn

comments.text: Actually, I've noticed it's the other way around. Saving in binary is way smaller than Ascii...Also, what was happening, was I would use RepG to center STL files after I exported from Rhino and that would more than double the STL files in size...I don't do that anymore. I just tested it just to make sure... Binary made the test model 3.2mb, Ascii made the file 24mb. I also have the simple planes and pack textures checked...Maybe I'm missing something else when I'm exporting? I really don't know Rhino very well.

title: 2X Extruder Upgrade for Raffle Alu-Cooling Block and Hot End

description.text:
I have installed Carl/Raffle's Alu-Dual Hot End & Cooling Block Upgrade http://shop.raffle.ch/shop/ and I needed some modifications to get mcniff's extruder upgrade http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:222667 working. What I did:
  • Added slight extrusion under stepper gear to help guide filament into the hole and to help prevent flexible filament from feeding/jamming under it (idea from thing 404636).
  • made opening for stepper gear slightly larger for better fit with the new guide-extrusion (I didn't want to have to remove the gear and get it re-aligned again).
  • Made the back indent slightly larger so it prints as a better fit over the stepper without needing a lot of sanding/finishing.
  • The important part! I adjusted the gap under the feed hole so it fits over the nut on the new Alu Hot End.
    • Some other designs removed a few mm of width to the assembly so it fits flush with the stepper and feeds directly into the hot end, but read Carl's instructions with the cooling block, you see that the spacer wasn't added to make it fit, it was added to intentionally force a gap between the cooling block and the stepper. Just note that if you cannot get longer mounting screws, you will have to discard the fan cover on the 2x. (fyi: Fastenal carries the long m3 screws needed. They may not be in stock, but they can order them for you :D) mcniff's http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:237554 works much better than the arms in the original.

Materials: (PER EXTRUDER)
  • 1 6mm m3 screw (mounts the under-arm side of the base)
  • 1 14mm m3 screw (mounts the arm and the other side of the base)
  • 1 Spring : I used C-624 "Utility Comp Spring" (9.525 x 28.575 x 1.041mm || 3/8 x 1-1/8 x .041) Century Spring Corp from ACE Hardware
  • 1 3x10x4 Bearing 623ZZ (http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B002BBF3JO/ref=wms_ohs_product?ie=UTF8&psc=1)
  • 1 9mm m3 screw (holds bearing in proper position in arm)
    • Print:
  • Upgraded Base piece
  • Arms and Cover from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:237554
  • 2.4mm Spacer from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:233971
    • I printed with 4 shells, 50% infill, and .15mm layer height. I used a Raft and Supports, and have found that printing it vertical (the orientation it would be when mounted) instead of on its back makes it need a LOT less clean-up. Just remove the supports, make sure the feeding holes are cleared out (I used a small hex wrench to make sure they were smooth), and install.

Hi everyone, I uploaded this Thing for you to test it out!
As this is a school project, there can be some flaws in the design that I overlooked but all should be fine.
The purpose if this design is to store your picks so that you can acces them quickly while playing guitar. It also mutes any excess noise from your strings when you play with a lot of gain or in lower tunings. This is based on "the Jimmy Clip", be sure to google it if you are interested.
You can put this on any 6-string guitar or anywhere you want, but it is designed to place it on the strings on the headstock of the guitar, after they leave the nut.
[EDIT] This is the first time I upload something here.
[EDIT] The general dimension of the whole part is 70x17x13 millimeters.

Look in the Gallery to see how you have to put it together.
I uploaded 4 files, but you only need "Top Part and "Bottom Part" for printing. The other 2 files are the rubber parts that go inside the clip, I just uploaded them so you can change it or if you want to check the dimensions.
For the bolt you can use an M2 bolt that is at least 20 millimeters long and a hex nut. For the spring you can use anything you want, as long as it is strong enough to keep the Thing on your guitar. I designed it with a 0,7 millimeter thick steel spring. The rubber parts are 49x14x5 millimeters and 49x14x2 millimeters. You can also use foam or even wood if you don't want to put it on your strings.
Another thing to notice is that the gaps for the picks are 1 millimeter wide, but you can edit this to your wish in any CAD program.
(I designed this with Autodesk Inventor Professional 2013.)

title: OpenSCAD Unit Testing and Documentation Tool

description.text:
OpenSCAD_DocTest is a library for documentation and unit testing of functions in OpenSCAD. Both doc and tests are written in arrays and processed by doctest() and output to the console. It has different modes like doc only, test only, show tests as examples (i.e., no testing), etc, and capable of commenting on test cases easily, making it a good tool for demonstrating demo of usages.
Whichever mode it operates on, the output (in the console) can be copied and pasted to a doc editor (like LibreOffice Writer), and an api doc can be generated with very minor editing. The file openscad_doctest_api.html servers as a good demo for this feature.
The unit test feature helps to ensure quality, reduces maintenance burden, facilitate re-factoring, and, my favorite, allows for test-first or test-driven programming, i.e., write the expected outcome of a function first, then starts writing the code to see if it behaves as expected.
NOTE: This lib is released as an open source under AGPL3 (that license is missing from Thingiverse's license option list when I created this thing).

• Run openscad_doctest_demo_1.scad for a quick taste of basics.
  • Run doctest_help(index) in openscad_doctest_help.scad to display help
  • Run doctest_tool_test(mode) in openscad_doctest_help.scad for a complete demo of testing all the unility functions that doctest uses.
    Here is a quick walk through for the flow of coding with example function: 
    function addz(p,z)= [p.x, p.y, p.z+z];

    a. Write doc: 

     addz=[ "addz"   // function name  
      , "p,z"    // arg names  
      , "array"  // return type  
      , "Array"  // category  
      , "Add z to the z of p."  // doc content  
 ];

    b. Write test: [ arg_string, result, expected] 

    module addz_test( mode=13 )  
 {  
    addz_tests=  
    [  
       ["[3,4,5],2", addz([3,4,5],2), [3,4,7] ]  
    ];   
    doctest( addz           // doc  
           , addz_tests     // tests  
           , ["mode",mode]  // options  
           );   
 }

    Or use local scope for variables: 

     module addz_test( mode=13 )  
 {  
    pt=[3,4,5];   // define test variables  
    addz_tests=  
    [  
       [ "pt,2", addz(pt,2), [3,4,7] ]        
    ];   
    doctest( addz           // doc  
           , addz_tests     // tests  
           , ["mode",mode]  // options  
           , ["pt",pt] );   // add scope  
           );   
 }

    c. Include this: 

    include <openscad_doctest.scad>   
addz_test( 13 );

comments.text: This is incredible! I can't wait to try it out. I'll let you know how I get on.

description.text:
It doesn't matter what you're trying to avoid, be it a rain storm or those pesky UV rays. Your creations would love to stay under this umbrella, so let them have their Mary Poppins moment. For those with a dual extruder, a two color version is included so you could stay dry in style.~
The OGOBILD attachments are interchangeable, safe, and functional toys you can use to create anything you can imagine. Now you can download, modify, and print out your own custom pieces.
You can print this at a low resolution but with a fairly high infill. No need for supports or a raft.

author: OgoSport

description.text: Update August 8th, 2014:

The Parsiotto version wasn't working very well since the neck wasn't getting any air, so I updated it to a V2, with a better air flow. It's a little bulkier but it might do the trick.
Update July 31st, 2014:
Following MrArrow1961's requests and suggestions, I have updated the files. Now I guess they can be printed without the bridge in the middle and thermal efficiency may have been improved.
This shroud will keep air from blowing on the printed part. I have supplied two versions for the hotends I currently use: magma and parisotto. Feel free to remix to fit your needs!

Print both halves then glue them around your hotend. Use just a couple of drops so you can easily tear it apart if needed. I didn't leave holes for the fan screws because I don't have screws that fit, so I drilled small holes on the bottom and used a wire to attach the fan. I also used a couple of drops of superglue just in case.

This is a breadboard workstation for electronics hobbyists. It involves 3D printed components, some electronics and a little bit of woodwork to construct. The 3D printed components are provided here, for a full description of the project, and how to build it, please look at http://thegaragelab.com/projects/breadboard-prototyping-station.html

There are a lot of variables involved in the construction, for a complete description on how to build your own you really need to look at the project page I set up for it - http://thegaragelab.com/projects/breadboard-prototyping-station.html. The files as provided are set up for the following:
  • A breadboard size of 175mm x 46mm x 8mm
  • A front riser of 20mm
  • A mounting plate at the back 45mm in length
    • If this is what you need (and you are going to design your own electronics) simply download 'bb_left.stl' and 'bb_right.stl' and print them. If you need to modify the dimensions you need to download 'breadboard.scad', 'bb_left.scad' and 'bb_right.scad' into the same directory and modify the variables at the top of 'breadboard.scad' as needed ('bb_left.scad' and 'bb_right.scad' simply include 'breadboard.scad' to do all the work and then rotate the output so it prints without overhangs). The file 'power_plate.scad' generates a mounting plate you can use to add sockets and switches to, the 'power_plate.stl' is the one I used for the components I have. If you want a mounting plate you will definitely have to modify the OpenSCAD file for the dimensions you need. I suggest starting with 'power_plate.scad' as a template - it's fairly well documented so you should be able to modify it fairly easily to match your requirements. As for the woodwork and electronics required - you really need to visit the project page I mentioned above, it's just a bit too much to squeeze into the instructions section here. If you have any questions or need any help please leave a comment here or at my site and I'll do my best to help you out.

title: Snap-on Dial Indicator Holder for Replicator 2

description.text:
Yes this is another Dial Indicator Holder, but this one is different! I tried one of the others, and found the whole approach rather silly - why sit the indicator holder on the gantry rails when you can clip it onto the extruder and use the jog controls in ReplicatorG to position it? With this clip-on dial indicator holder you will get repeatable results, because you are relying on the extruder rail bushes to position the dial indicator over the levelling screws on the build plate. UPDATE (13 Feb 2013)
There are two new STEP files which can be imported into other CAD programs. The first can be customised with your own hole size to suit different types of indicators. The other is a blank holder that can be used to design your own attachments. There is also a new script that automates the process so you don't even have to use ReplicatorG any more to control the process. The gcode has been exported as an x3g file - ready to download to your printer's SD card. Version 2 of my Clip-on Indicator Holder is compatible with my Replicator 2 Extruder Upgrade http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:42250 This indicator holder was designed using an ACIS solid in Shark FX (sfx file included) so will behave well with Makerware, ReplicatorG and skeinforge. Because a few of you have asked - Paypal donations graciously accepted - whpthomas at yahoo dot com

I purchased a cheap dial indicator from Hong Kong for $10 on eBay - which is plenty good enough for the tolerances we are dealing with. PRINTING I used my 200 micron ReplicatorG profile http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39050 Infill 30%
Layer Height 0.2mm
Number of shells 2 Once you have finished the print, push the dial indicator into the mounting hole. My indicator's mounting shaft pokes out about 2mm from the bottom. LEVELLING THE BUILD PLATFORM First time, run your usual bed levelling procedure. For best results, use a 0.1 mm feeler gauge, or the support card if that is all you have, then run my interactive build platform levelling aid http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:39430 to make sure the nozzle offset is just right. This procedure takes a bit of extra time and wastes some filament, but once you have the base layer printing evenly, you can use this nozzle offset to calibrate the dial indicator, so any time in future if you want to re-level your build platform all you need is your clip-on dial indicator to get the same result. AUTOMATIC LEVELLING Download the x3g automatic script file and install it on your printer's SD card. DO NOT clip on the holder onto extruder before running the script! Select Build From SD on the printer's menu and run the levelling script. The script will home, then centre and ask you to clip-on dial indicator holder. It will then position over each successive thumbscrew prompting you to make adjustments, and then over the centre. The dial indicator is positioned 0.2mm off the build surface to make sure it clears any residue left on the tip of the nozzle. Finally the script lowers the build plate and asks you to unclip the dial indicator holder - Make sure you do! I recommend you keep this script on an SD card with all your levelling and calibration objects. MANUAL LEVELLING Open ReplicatorG and select Machine->Control Panel from the menu, and set the Jog Mode to 20mm. Note: If at any time your Replicator 2 starts acting strange, like is has a mind of its own - like you try to drop the z axis and it just keeps going with other axes firing up - Don't Panic - hit the STOP button in the control panel. Exit the control panel, and click Reset, Disconnect and then Connect. This should clear out any gremlins. Not sure why it happens but it does every now and then. Then do the following: 1) Home all axes (from the menu). 2) Using the jog buttons in the control panel dialog, drop the Z axis and move the extruder along the x axis so its roughly in the middle. 3) Clip on the dial indicator holder by aligning it on the bottom edge and pivoting the top over so the tab clips it into place (see photo). The edge of the tab should rub up against the filament feed tube. 4) Now using the jog buttons in the control panel dialog, position extruder on the x and y axis so the dial indicator is above the rear levelling screw. Then move the Z axis back up until it hits the end stop switch. 5) If this is your first time doing this, zero your indicator - or adjust how far into the holder the indicator is inserted so the zero position is where you want it. On my indicator, I wanted the zero to be at the top, so I adjusted the indicator by wiggling it back and forth while supporting the holder it with my other hand to adjust how far it was inserted. I did this until the needle lined up to the zero marker. Once you have already done this, you can ignore this step - but leave your indicator alone, so next time you want to level your build plate, your dial indicator holder will be ready to go. This works because this snap-on holder registers against the bottom of the extruder where it clips on, enabling repeatable results. If you need your indicator for other projects, maybe its time to spring for a cheap second one on ebay. I like the mechanical ones better because they provide repeatability, responsive feedback, and the batteries never run out. 6) Use the jog buttons to move the extruder and position the dial indicator over each of the remaining level screws and adjust them to move the build plate up or down until the indicator needle is on zero. 7) Move the nozzle back to the centre and double check the nozzle distance with your feeler gauge. 8) Drop the z axis and unclip the dial indicator holder at the top by lifting the tab and pivoting away to remove. All up, this procedure takes just a few minutes to level the Replicator 2 build platform, and the results appear to be accurate and repeatable. WARNING Don't run the levelling procedure or home the extruder with the indicator attached, or you will crash your indicator into the side of the gantry. So make sure you remember to unclip and remove it when you are done ;)

remixed_from.title: Filament Spool Clip for 3 mm and 1.75 mm

description.text: I have some spools with thin flanges (4mm), and the original clip design is too loose for it. This new clip fits perfectly

We lost some of the plastic parts that hold/stop the shelves on the support rods... so we printed some new ones.
These should work with some shelves from Costco and Safco brand shelves, but may also work with others..
The STL file is for 1/2, so you need to print 2 for a complete part.
This is a lithophane of the famous Mona Lisa (La Gioconda) by Leonardo da Vinci. http://www.3dwp.nl

When printed in FDM it's best to print on a side (upright) to benefit from the layer resolution, also PLA is better because of less warping. The one in the picture was printed upright in white PLA (0.15 mm layers) on a PP3DP Up! Plus. It's best to use opaque material like white or yellow, ABS is possible but will warp more because of the thin structure. -->If people have a request for another lithophane (of any picture) just put it in the comments.<-- http://www.3dwp.nl

remixed_from.author: Simonious
remixed_from.title: x-axis belt tie down for rail

title: Vertical X-axis Belt Mount with Built-in Tensioner

description.text:
Vertical X-axis belt tie down for PBC linear slide on MendelMax 1.5. This version does not require the use of cable ties or large screw down clamps and includes a built-in belt tensioner.
Grooves in the mount are designed to tightly trap the standard GT2 2mm pitch 6mm wide timing belts used on the MendelMax.  The grooves are designed to be tight and you might have to push the belt in with a small flat screw driver.
Let me know if you want the SolidWorks file, just a fair warning it is not the neatest design I have ever created and is kind of a mess.

Requires: 5 x 10mm M3 (Four for mounting, one for cap)
1 x 25mm M3 (For tensioner)
1 x M3 Nut
1 x M3 Acorn Nut Print, assemble the tensioner and mount on back of X-carriage. Mount the closed end (left side) of the belt in the groove first, then loop the belt around the motor and idler and pull it tight before looping it around the acorn nut and through the bottom groove. Get it as tight as you can without over-tightening. Once the belt is in the groove you will have ~15mm of tensioning distance. Tighten as needed and close with cap to prevent the belts from sliding out. The screw holding on the cap is not load bearing so instead of making room for a nut trap I just made the hole tight enough for the screw to cut its own thread.

title: Snap-Together Valentine Gears Pin and Pendant
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Previously, I designed a gear set on a heart for Valentine's Day (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:242304) that requires fixing the gears in place by melting, hence deforming, the tops of the gears' axles. This works, but is very tricky since PLA (my favorite filament type) melts really easily. It demands a very light touch!
I finally was able to produce a design that allows easy snap-together construction. This is it!
I should mention that the gears presented here are essentially the same as before, but have slightly larger center holes. Any old gears you have can be used with the new bases, but it would be easier to enlarge the holes before snapping the gears in place.
Size: approx. 2" high x 1-3/4" wide (5 cm x 4 cm) NEW: Please check out the frames for the pin & pendant that make for a more finished look at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:422248.

I printed with 0.2mm layer height, 3 shells, and 30% infill. The latter may be unnecessary, but I was looking for strength.
In one example, I dry brushed (sort of) dark red acrylic paint on the base (excluding pins) and gold acrylic on the gears. The other two are entirely printed. One has golden gears - really shiny! - made of BuMat PLA 1.75mm Gold Filament.

description.text: This is an end table, made from printed component "cans."  You can have a new table every day by changing the position of the colors or patterns on the "cans."  LED lights or motion detectors can be placed inside the "cans" for interactive furniture.  If you're having a party, remove the end table glass, add a few "cans" and a different top for a buffet table.
With the MakerBot Replicator, this is a big print job--about 14 hours per "can."

title: Holder for large spools (e.g. 10 lb PLA)

description.text: I bought a 10 lb spool of PLA and needed something to hold it. Here's a simple holder made out of 3/4" Type L copper pipe, with 3D printed corner pieces.

Print four of the "60 degree corner for type L 3-4 copper pipe.stl" and two of the "60 degree corner for type L 3-4 and 1-2 copper pipe.stl". I used 5 shells and 50% infill, they have to be pretty solid as they are designed for an interference fit and need to be put on with a mallet. You will actually shave off a bit of plastic as you assemble the frame, but once assembled the frame is solid, no screws or pins required.
You will need six pieces of Type L 3/4" copper pipe for the sides - the exact length will depend on the specific spool you are making this for, but the important thing is that all six are the same length as we are making two equilateral triangles.
Then, you need two more pieces of 3/4" Type L for the crossbars at the base - again, specific length depends on your spool, but they have to match each other. For both sets, I would eyeball the first one, and then use that first one as a ruler to get the rest the same. A pipe cutter is much better than a hacksaw for this. Note that it matters what tubing type you use, as the internal diameter is different for the same nominal pipe size in Type L vs K or M. If you use a different tubing type (or e.g. conduit, or something else) you may need to scale the corner pieces to fit.
Assembling the sides is a bit tricky, it is easiest to put one piece of side tubing onto each corner piece. Then assemble three of those into a triangle by tapping each of the corners in a little bit, turning and repeating until the triangle is fully assembled. Note that you need to make sure you have all the orientations correct (lay everything out beforehand to make sure), and when you are using the mallet make sure your strikes are parallel to the direction of insertion, or you can shear off the 3D printed posts.
Then put the two crossbars onto one of the triangles, add the other triangle, and you're done. There is a bit of flexibility that will allow you to insert the spool,
Optionally, you could cut two little stubs of 1/2" pipe to fit onto the smaller posts that support the spool axis. These will increase wear resistance and likely decrease friction, but I am just using it with the bare printed posts and it's working OK so far. If they are too long you will have trouble bending the sides apart to load the spool, and note that if you cut one full length crosspiece instead, once you have assembled the holder you won't be able to insert or remove the spool at all.

This is a connector which uses 3mm makerbot magnets as the terminals.  The magnet are oriented so that their polarity allows all three terminals to contact in only one orientation.    I use these on my motorcycle to run 5V, GND, and signal between an arduino based GPS and an LCD with a serial board.  I designed it for a quick disconnect application, I use them on the bike this way to make sure they could deal with the vibration.  So far so good!

Print and clean the part with an exacto knife. For each wire:
Strip and flatten the ends of a 22AWG solid wire. Hook the flattened, stripped end of each wire into a corner of the connector. Hooking the wire will help keep it in place for the next step. Press the magnet (in the desired orientation) into the square slot on top of the wire end, so that part of the wire is pressed between the magnet and the vertical slot wall closest to the connector corner. Route the wire through the strain relief slots extending from the center hole.

You could try using a solder with a lower melting temperature (like many leaded) lower than the curie temperature for neodymium magnets.

TP Tube Cap: 43.3mm in diameter to fit standard toilet paper and household paper towel tubes.
Extra Hook: A few people mentioned having a problem with their hooks, so this is a hook that you can glue onto a previously printed cap.

Printed this using the following settings:
Infil: 75%
Supports: On
Shells: 2
Layer Height: 0.20 mm
Print, snap on an elastic, store stuff.

description.text: A raised BSA logo on a palm-sized coin (scaled to 25%)
scale to 25% for a palm-sized coin.

Fulfill your childhood dreams of becoming a Pokemon Master with this full sized Pokeball! This model features a hinged lid that opens when the button is pressed and locks shut to allow you to store things inside the ball. It also includes a stand to display your Pokeball.
Once you print all the parts, check out our video on assembly:
http://youtu.be/jvgK3_UdLdg EDIT: We have added alternate lids for the great ball, ultra ball, and master ball. EDIT [9/8/2015]: We have added scaled down (20% smaller) versions of all of the parts with modified tolerances for optimal for printing at smaller scales.

Instructions: You will need:
  • All 6 printed parts
  • Super Glue
  • A small spring ~1.75 cm long (you can find these in ball point pens and mechanical pencils)
  • Sandpaper
  • An extra piece of 1.75 mm thick filament ~2.75 cm long
    .
    Follow this link for a video on how to assemble the Pokeball http://youtu.be/jvgK3_UdLdg
    .
    We printed all of the parts using a 0.2 mm layer height and 10% infill. We used support material for all of the parts. Make sure that you carefully remove all of the support material and sand down the rim of the lid (this is important to get the lid to lock correctly). Make sure to remove the support material from the 3 grooves on the rim of the bottom of the Pokeball as well. It is also a good idea to make sure that the whole assembly works properly before gluing the parts together.

comments.text: I have added two new part files: Loop_Top ALTERNATE and Loop_Bottom ALTERNATE. These modified loop parts have 3 sockets on the inside rims of the loop parts and the Loop_Top Alternate part prints with 3 pins. Simply glue the pins into the sockets on one of the loop parts and then match up the pins with the sockets on the other loop part. (If you use support material, remember to remove it from the sockets)
PERFECT!

comments.author: theman00011

comments.text: You need to print the top half right side up with support material. Then remove the support material and use sandpaper to make sure that the rim is smooth. If you don't get the support material off completely then the lid might not latch correctly. Also be sure to remove the support material from inside the hinge. You can either drill out the support material or find a metal rod (we used a hex key) and heat up one end with a lighter and use it to melt the support material out.

A variation of this Shepherd's whistle I made:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:360499
This one plays a deeper and louder bass sound, but can't hit the same high notes as the original.

Slic3r settings I used...(probably not the best):
Layer height: .3mm
perimeters: 5
infill:.3mm
fill pattern: octagramspiral (slow)
combine infill every:3
How to use Shepherd's whistle:
  • With the back of your tongue placed on the flat surface of the whistle, blow gently.
  • Your tongue is directing the airflow to the top of the whistle and through the hole (you want to make sure your tongue prevents any air from getting under the whistle)
  • A pocket of air forms under the whistle and as the air pressure increases, it forces itself back out the hole.
  • Air escapes through the slit that divides the top and bottom and whistles.
    You can change the whistle's tone and pitch by making different formations with your mouth and blowing louder or softer.
    • Here's a video of a guy who is very talented at playing this type of whistle: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Mv66viUCn1Y

0% infill
2 shells
ABS
125 mm tall
300 micron slice
makes a light fast print.

comments.text: What are you using to finish these models?  An acetone wash?  Look nice and smooth....
comments.author: ukcat

comments.text:
Acetone Hot Vapor Polish:
I use a asparagus cooking pot.
I have a flat disc on the bottom of the "basket"
Heat the acetone on a hotplate with a clear glass lid so I can watch.
usually takes under 1 minute (closer to 30 seconds)
I just watch the condensation on the model [it wets from the bottom up]
once it is done wetting, I just pull the basket and let it air dry for 2 minutes.
so really under 5 minutes total, and my rig was bought at a tag sale so dirt cheap!
Frankly I think the results show a 300Micron print once treated
actually has a better finish than a untreated 100 micron print,
and in fact it makes the layers bind together much stronger than untreated.
I like to post pics of the print before and after treatment to contrast.
One final point, In using ABS, I keep a jar of acetone/ABS slurry
that I use to dab on small holes in prints, or as a 'glue'.
following with vapor polish helps make the model's finish uniform
and hides the filled in holes.

title: Screw cap for UP Printer heating plate screws

description.text: This is a little screw cap that you can print on your UP Printer and then glue onto the heads of the screws that hold the print platform to the heater base. This allows you to easily remove the print platform without needing the Allen key. I use epoxy to glue them onto the screws andput it in a little vice until the epoxy dries.
Print on your UP printer with the screw hole facing upwards, and when finished use epoxy glue to glue it to the screw heads. Calmp in vice to kkep compressed until the epoxy dries.

A remix of Snille's Wire chain. I had been trying, but had issues with printing the overhang on the bottom Once I had adjusted print settings to get that right the pieces would delaminate when trying to clip them together. Also I had some a lot tighter then others. I guess because of the different print settings.
So Ive changed it to use a peice of 3mm filament as a pin. Its loose on the inside peice, and a press fit on the outside. Im thinking a bit of melting with a soldering iorn or glue just to be sure. Ive also made in 10mm longer and 5mm wider, just to reduce the number of peices for a given length and to accommodate more wires.

title: Desktop Fishbowl Aquaponics
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
This is a self-sustained fishbowl aquaponics. It separates the roots of your plant and the growing medium from the fishbowl. This creation spawned as result of a solution for my fiance's project.
The growing chamber located above the the fishbowl (based on a standard fishbowl purchased form Wal-Mart),, is isolated from the aquatic environment below. This allows for the root zone to grow to its full potential without inhibiting the life below. The plant acts as a natural filter feeding off the waste of the fish and the fish acts as a natural fertilizer. This symbiotic relationship provides for convenience maintenance of the life above and below the water line.
Aerated water is supplemented to the root chamber through means of airlift pump, thus both oxygenating the water and separating air bubbles from the aquatic environment. This allows for the user to have a greater option of fish that prefer still water, for example: Beta Fish and Gold Fish.
This item is released for means of beta testing. Feel free to iterate and provide feedback as necessary. This item is Patent Pending, the manufacturing, distribution and/ or retail of the " Desktop Fishbowl Aquaponics," is unlawful. Thank You

Print with Air Lift pump and Fishbowl Aquaponics Lid with no suppot.
2 Shells
20% Infill
3 Top and Bottom Solid
Materials:
Fishbowl
Aquarium Air Pump
ABS Plastic
Air Hose
2" Net Pot
Grow Medium: Hydroton, Crushed Glass, Lava Rock

english:
Take a closer look! This thing allows you, to mount a lens reverse to your camera for makroshots of very small things. You have to hotglue a uv-filter on the printed adapter, so you can mount the fitting lens. In my case I used a 52mm diameter filter to attach an old manual lens. Lenses with electronic lens opening will only work in widest open mode. Feel free to use and modify this thing!
More pics:
https://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/ german:
Schau mal genauer hin! Dieser Adapter erlaubt die umgedrehte Montage eines Objektivs an deiner Kamera. Mit Heißkleber muss ein entsprechender UV-Filter an den Adapter geklebt werden um das Objektiv sicher montieren zu können. In meinem Fall habe ich einen mit 52mm Filtergewinde genommen um ein altes manuelles Objektiv zu montieren. Neurere Objektive mit elektronischer Blende funktionieren auch, allerdings nur mit Offenblende. Gerne darf das Teil verbessert oder abgeändert werden.
Mehr Bilder
https://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/

comments.text:
Take a look at my http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:414556
You can directly print a working 0.75mm-pitch filter thread using the 45-degree trick there.

This enclosure is designed to bolt to a heat sink, not pictured here.  The square opening is for access to the heat sink so that the voltage regulator can be bolted directly to the heat sink.  You may want to drill out/tap some of these holes.

title: Arduino to Raspberry Pi Mount V1.0

description.text: A system to securely mount an Arduino to your Raspberry Pi.

Arduino to Raspberry Pi Mount Features in V1.0:
  • Mounts an Arduino to a Raspberry Pi leaving access for all connection points.
  • Uses all existing mounting points
  • Cut aways to allow for under-hanging solder points on Arduino.
  • Holes sized to self-tap when M3 bolt is used
  • Perfect for more permanent Arduino-to-Pi builds using the UART pins
    • You will need:
  • Raspberry Pi (V2.0 or later - Previous Pis have no mounting holes),
  • Arduino (Uno, Leonardo, Ethernet, Duemilanove),
  • Small M3 Bolts/Screws (Length 5-15mm)
    • To Build:
    Please use the pictures 3, 4, 5 and 6 as a guide to build.
    M3 bolts needed ( I bought 100 M3x6mm for Â£2.99 from the local DIY store) Future features:
    More features currently under development including boltless construction, feet for the Raspberry Pi and More...

A version of my lighthouse created in OpenSCAD. 
Added a version LH2. Just added some labels to help if you are changing it. I also hollowed out the tower and figured out how to make more post for the top of the lighthouse as well. Whoever made the code for example 5, it is pretty sweet and easily adaptable!

I created a dual struded version and Printed at 5% and accellerated. Driving me batty that is still staggers. Printed the one color version and it is fine. I am baffled about the dual print. My step for creating the 2 stl files was like this.
1) saved light house as lhred.
2) deleted the code for the parts that I wanted to be white... then saved and exported as a stl.
3) loaded the original light house and did the same steps above, but deleted the code for the red parts.
4) Merged those 2 files in replicatorG 040. Is there anything goofy I am missing? Thanks.
Mike
